content.user_title: Create AI Skills with Workflows and Tools
content.value_statement: Building custom AI skills requires understanding complex workflows and best practices. This skill guides you through creating specialized skills with scripts, references, and assets that extend Claude's capabilities.
actual_capabilities: Guides creation of skills with YAML frontmatter metadata
Provides templates for scripts, references, and assets organization
Explains progressive disclosure design for context management
Details tool restrictions and allowed-tools configuration
Includes step-by-step skill creation and testing process
limitations: Does not create skills automatically - provides guidance only
Requires manual implementation of scripts and assets
No validation of skill syntax or structure
Limited to documentation and best practices

use_cases.title: Create Custom AI Skills
use_cases.description: Build specialized skills for your team with custom workflows, scripts, and documentation that Claude can use automatically.

use_cases.title: Document Team Workflows
use_cases.description: Convert your team's standard operating procedures into AI skills that ensure consistent execution across projects.

use_cases.title: Extend Claude's Capabilities
use_cases.description: Create personal skills that add domain expertise and automate repetitive tasks you perform regularly.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Skill Creation
prompt_templates.scenario: Create a simple file processing skill
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me create a skill that converts CSV files to JSON format. Include a Python script and clear instructions for Claude to follow.

prompt_templates.title: Complex Workflow Skill
prompt_templates.prompt: I need a skill that helps deploy web applications. It should check code quality, run tests, build assets, and deploy to production with rollback capability.

prompt_templates.title: Reference-Heavy Skill
prompt_templates.scenario: Create a skill with extensive documentation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a skill for working with our company's API. Include authentication details, rate limits, endpoint documentation, and example requests in the references folder.

prompt_templates.title: Asset-Based Skill
prompt_templates.scenario: Build a skill with templates and boilerplate
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me create a skill that generates React components. Include TypeScript templates, styling examples, and testing boilerplate in the assets folder.

output_examples.input: Create a skill that helps analyze log files
output: - scripts/parse_logs.py for parsing different log formats

best_practices: Start with concrete examples of how the skill will be used before writing instructions
Keep SKILL.md focused on one capability and under 5,000 words
Use imperative form in instructions: 'Execute the script' not 'You should execute'
anti_patterns: Creating skills that try to do everything - keep them focused on one capability
Duplicating information between SKILL.md and references files
Using second person instructions that confuse the AI reading the skill

faq.question: What tools can skills use?
faq.answer: Skills can use all Claude tools including Read, Write, Bash, WebFetch, Task, and more. Use allowed-tools to restrict if needed.

faq.question: How large can reference files be?
faq.answer: Reference files can be unlimited size. For files over 10,000 words, include grep search patterns in SKILL.md for efficient access.

faq.question: Can skills include executable code?
faq.answer: Yes, scripts in the scripts/ folder can be Python, Bash, or other languages. They execute directly without loading into context.

faq.question: Where should I store my skills?
faq.answer: Store in .claude/skills/ for project-specific or ~/.claude/skills/ for personal skills. Both locations work automatically.

faq.question: How do I test my skill?
faq.answer: Use the skill on real tasks, identify struggles, update instructions or resources, and iterate until it works smoothly.

faq.question: What's the difference between skills and slash commands?
faq.answer: Skills are AI-triggered based on context, while slash commands are user-triggered. Use skills for capabilities users might forget to invoke.
